org.guicebox.failover
Class Failover

java.lang.Object
  org.guicebox.failover.Failover
All Implemented Interfaces:
Cluster
@ThreadSafe
public class Failover
extends Object
implements Cluster

Implements a simple but effective active-passive failover strategy for high availability. There is a maximum of one primary node in the cluster, which advertises its status via UDP heartbeats. The backup node (usually one, but there can be more) waits for a cessation of heartbeats and assumes the role of primary. All nodes continuously ping a well-known address (WKA), ideally a virtual IP that has failover of its own, to ensure that they have network connectivity. This is so a backup node can know whether it has stopped receiving heartbeats because the primary node has died or because it has lost its own connectivity to the network.

Each node can be in exactly one of the following NodeStates:

  1. DISCONNECTED - The node cannot contact the WKA.
  2. BACKUP - The node is connected to the network and receiving heartbeats from the primary.
  3. VOLUNTEER - The node has volunteered to take over as primary.
  4. PRIMARY - The node is currently active and working.
All nodes start up in the DISCONNECTED state, until they have confirmed network connectivity by pinging the WKA. Once a ping response is received, the node transitions to the BACKUP state, and waits for heartbeats from a PRIMARY. If no heartbeat is received within the configured timeout, the node transitions through VOLUNTEER to PRIMARY state and begins sending heartbeats of its own.

If two or more nodes simultaneously attempt to become PRIMARY, they will receive each other's heartbeats. A combination of start time and IP address is used to statically determine which node(s) should yield.

See GuiceBox documentation for details.

Author:
willhains

join

public void join(Application app)
Description copied from interface: Cluster
Join the cluster. The cluster implementation takes over responsibility for starting/stopping the application, by calling to the specified application control object. The implementation must tolerate calls to this method when already joined to or joining the cluster.

Specified by:
join in interface Cluster
Parameters:
app - control for starting/stopping the application.

leave

public void leave()
Description copied from interface: Cluster
Leaves the cluster. The cluster implementation relinquishes responsibility for starting/stopping the application. This method is called when the application explicitly tells GuiceBox to stop or kill the application, implying that it has taken over responsibility for the GuiceBox state for now. The implementation must tolerate calls to this method when already left or leaving the cluster.

Specified by:
leave in interface Cluster
